title: [Poll] Were Keystones were a mistake? Discussion inside!
body:
People complain that tanks are weak and honestly, I've made it known I strongly disagree. However, I will not deny for a second that keystones have made this game a nightmare to balance and have warped the games balance so many times this season.
And much of that is because reliable damage keystones like thunderlords and fervor can give literally anything the ability to do damage while not paying much for it in return.

People talk about tanks dying instantly, again I disagree but let's not forget that for half of this season, tanks were running grasp (which does pretty considerable damage honestly) or thunderlords and were running around killing everything while being incredibly hard to kill. 

No matter what meta we are in, and I'd argue we are in a strange state where a little bit of everything is good right now, the amount of reliable damage any class can put out is absurd. And that kind of damage come from all classes is bad for the game, both balance wise and for just the sheer experience. Nobody enjoys playing against a champion that typically builds glass or semi glass and decides they will go full tank and abuse fervor/grasp procs. Nobody likes playing against semi glass or glass champions that build Trinity and tank after that and abuse Trinity procs + fervor. These are a few examples that illustrate my point.

In reality, the issue is this: runes and masteries should not be this game changing/warping. There's enough variables as is to consider when it comes to balancing and when you begin balancing around masteries that will eventually be changed anyway, you further set the game into a state of chaos. The old mastery system was fine, much like the rune system is fine now. Yes its stale but it has to be because otherwise you get this mess.

I urge you to consider removing keystones this coming season and simply go back to a more simplistic mastery system so we aren't spending chunks of a season running the same 2 mastery setups on every class until the next setup is buffed while the old one is being nerfed. And despite all of this and the attempt of making masteries more interesting, in reality the masteries with keystones have just become more boring. That tells you how flawed this idea is.

Honestly I like the idea of the keystones as they (in theory) allow for more options and decision making at the end of a tree.  Unlike previous masteries where it was another big number at the end of them.  

The problem with the masteries is that some are just superior to others when it comes to damage.  Whichever does the most damage the easiest tends to become the more common and frustrating mastery to deal with.

Take the League of Thunderlords problem.  TLD was the strongest damage keystone after the Warlords fix and Deathfire nerfs.  Not only that, but it was incredibly versatile in activating its damage.  Three hits and BOOM, thunder.  Three spells that hit champions, three attacks that hit champions, 2 attacks and a spell, 2 spells and an attack, etc, all of these were combos that would set it off.  The mastery was originally built (imo) with combo casting champions in mind, but anyone could benefit from it and do so very well.  

Then was have Grasp of the Undying, which is my favorite mastery.  It would allow beefy champions who normally lacked damage (also allowed juggernauts) to get some damage from their defensive stats.  This and the sustain made low sustain tanks function better in top lane.  But with the addition of several factors (mainly a massive damage increase) everyone started building more tanky and grabbed that tank mastery because SoTA isn't good for laning and Bond is more of a support tank mastery.  

The sad truth is that people don't care about how they apply their damage.  Whether it be DoT, burst, sustain, or whatever.  What the majority of people care about when dealing damage is doing the most damage possible.  So whatever mastery is strongest at the time (even if it doesn't fit well with their champion) is the one that will be used most often and people will then start crying for nerfs.

Riot wanted to introduce diversity with keystones, but they have proven unable to really work out well.  Some masteries are just too good for niche champions, and others (Windspeaker, stormraiders) are just too niche to be considered for the champions that would work best with them.

I've seen {{champion:37}} and {{champion:16}} run both TLD and Windspeakers, but I've seen more TLD than I have windspeakers on the two healing heavy supports.  Course this is just my personal experience and I haven't played in a week.  

I applaud Riot for trying to add more diversity, but really they just show one of the biggest problems in the community (which in turn can be taken as a problem with the overall balance of their game): Whatever does the most damage/most benefit is going to be abused by the community at large in order to win more.  

Because that's what people want.  To win by almost any means necessary.
keystones don't give you a choice the way they are currently. they simply make some champs superior to others.

You can't blame the community or anyone for taking the best course of action to win, which most of the time is also the easiest. The easier and more reliable it is, the more consistent it does therefore the more likely it is to win. I will do whatever it takes to win in ranked games and that branches out even down to how I'll setup runes and masteries accordingly. 

I just don't think runes/masteries should have such power. Many items in this game alone have a ton of power and factor in all the kits we have in this game and you begin to see how many variables there are to balance out. Keystones add another layer to an already complex and chaotic system of balance. If items or champion kits were weaker or simpler, I think keystones would be a great addition. But in league of legends, that's simply not just the case. A good example of what I mean is Renekton with fervor. Let him hit you with a full fury W and watch this alone take 70% of your HP in the early game. Much of that has to do with how it stacks fervor and 20% of that damage is probably from fervor alone. The game has too many complexities for something like that to be existing imo.

The pros have become unconscious shepherds (by which I mean they do not intend to create the meta, they just try to do the very best they can to win.  Since that's their job) while we the playerbase (I.E. the herd) follow their direction because we want what they get: Victory.


At this point it's just nature.

Yeah, but for stuff like Sona, not played in pro, there isn't any real shepherd. And **IF** the game is "actually balanced" (meaning, Windspeaker is indeed better than TLD on Sona, for instance), but the community plays sub-optimally, Riot can't really buff Windspeaker until it's OP.

The keystones in general are a really nifty concept. They are supposed to be strong effects that have the potential to change the way you play your champion/play against the enemy champion.

The issue is, imo, that a) the defensive mastery tree is comparatively too weak and b) 3 of the damage keystones are too general and c) we are lacking a real defensive keystone.

The issue described in b) relates to the fact that neither Fervor of Battle nor Thunderlord's nor Grasp change anything in the way you need to play your champion - Fervor simply gives your auto-attacks more punch for continously auto-attacking, Thunderlord's adds a really boring damage spike on applying three instances of damage and Grasp rewards you for brawling.

A real defensive keystone could be, for example, a directional shield - think Fiora's passive, but instead of extra damage, it reduces damage coming in from the direction of the effect. It even could be something that works against all damage or only specific damage types...

I do think it's a better system than the other, however, maybe just tweak some of the keystones. Also I think that the lvl 18 and lvl 20 power spikes make the leveling process very poor for newer players. Make the keystones unavailable until level 30 to prevent that huge lvl 18 power spike and create an unfun experience for anyone under level 18 who is facing against those players.

Understand that the game was balanced around the old system and that balancing the keystone masteries is a process.

Keystones ruined this season along with the poor reworks that had to be nerfed after terrorizing the rift.

Here's what's up: keystones add strategic diversity to the mastery set up. Previously, you would just dump 21 point in offense because it was just better, and literally everyone other than supports ran 21/9/0. This way, you can run much more unique mastery sets depending on your champion and your playstyle. Obviously some champs are much better with certain keystones, but you can adapt somewhat depending on the matchup.

The issue is that riot has simply allowed them to be 110% OVERPOWERED AS FUCK FOR NEARLY A YEAR. There are no tradeoffs in build paths, because you can just get damage from your  keystone and build full tank and faseroll people. If riot just sits down for 5 fkin minutes and figures out how to balance the free damage from the keystones (ie make them scale instead of just being free flat damage) they should work fine.

Fervor, TLD, DFT and Grasp need some serious work IMO, if not flat out removal. TLD gives unhealthy burst patterns to already bursty champions. Fervor gives free damage, which allows for champions like Yasuo to build mostly tank and pick up this mastery and still have relevant damage. I really think these two keystones need to go.
it's kinda dumb that can't get a buff because TLD gives her the damage she's missing, remove them so we can balance champions and not champions and keystones; or just rework it.
